title: 107_s1686
content: The Act titled "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001" is cited as the short title. The Congress recognizes the importance of adequate and safe healthcare delivery, supported by research showing better patient outcomes with higher nurse staffing levels. Despite difficulties in recruiting and retaining nursing staff, healthcare providers still rely on mandatory overtime, contributing to nurse dissatisfaction and departures from the profession. The Comptroller General of the United States reported that health care providers use mandatory overtime, leading to nurse fatigue and compromising patient safety. Limiting mandatory overtime will ensure public safety, quality care, and nurse retention. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider Agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. A provider of services is prohibited from enforcing mandatory overtime, except as specified in the subsection. The Social Security Act now includes limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. Providers cannot require nurses to work beyond scheduled shifts or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period or 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period, except during declared emergencies for exceptional medical services. The Social Security Act limits mandatory overtime for nurses, allowing them to work beyond scheduled shifts or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period or 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period only during declared emergencies for exceptional medical services. Nurses can only be required to work longer if the provider has tried to fill staffing needs through other means and the work requirement ends when the state of emergency is over or the nurse's direct role in the emergency response ends. The Social Security Act limits mandatory overtime for nurses during declared emergencies for exceptional medical services. Nurses can file complaints against providers who violate this provision, and the Secretary will investigate these complaints. The Secretary will investigate complaints of violations filed by nurses. If a provider violates the provisions, they must establish a plan of action to correct it, and civil money penalties may be imposed. Nurses are protected from discrimination in any aspect of employment by providers of services. Nurses are protected from discrimination in employment, including refusal to work mandatory overtime or reporting violations. The Secretary can impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of regulations by a provider of services.
